data.title: Historic Interest in NYC corruption
data.text: The Tweed Courthouse is now the home of the New York City Department of Education. BTW, NYC has the largest and most diverse public school system in the USA.  The building has a notorious history.  In the late 1800s, the city was controlled by a public group called Tammany Hall, led by the infamous Boss Tweed.  The construction of the building led to massive cost overruns that were funneled to Boss Tweed and his cronies. There are some wonderful John Nash cartoons of Boss Tweed that visitors can check out online.  The building is right next to City Hall and near the foot entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge.  Worth a brief visit of the exterior.  A sad lesson in corruption.

data.title: Exquiste renovations
data.text: This is not a public space with considerable security to enter.  It housed the NYC Department (BOARD of Education.  The renovations done to this building are something to behold.

data.title: "Wow!! "You can almost see Boss Tweed and his cronies in here"
data.text:
take an hour and do the tour at the Tweed courthouse if you are into historic architecure of New York and incredible stories of "Tammany Hall" this is for you.too bad it is under utilized for municipal offices this should be a venue and event space terrific....... the meeting space and old courtrooms a real hoot !!!
Believe me troops this is a fun 2 hours mid week right after lunch,
Jimbo Bateso

data.title: Not Easy to Get Into but If a Tour is Offered...Go
data.text: I used to work in this building, and it was quite the spectacle: Boss Tweed, once ruler of NYC siphoned off millions of dollars from the endless construction of the courthouse that bears his name. It became the headquarters for the NYC Department of Education circa 2002, and is only open via guided tour, hence my title. It has some very grand rooms, complete with fireplaces, the views are expansive out over City Hall Park, the stone and brickwork are the best (hey--$$$$$). The lowest floor has been redone for student classrooms, and is colorful and creative. Basically, it's a grand spectacle with a  larger than life atrium descending from top of bulding to bottom! Stop in across the street to see the similarly jaw dropping Municipal Library lobby. Sit in beautiful City Hall Park, adjoining Tweed Courthouse, and then go walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, which you'll see from the park.

data.title: So much old NYC history
data.text: A beautiful old gem that is full of history and great tales. One of those " if the walls could only talk" kind of places. If you are in the area, stop in. It is soooooo NYC.

data.title: old world charm
data.text: I was there for a professional visit and its beautiful inside and out you won't have full access to the building as the NYC education department runs out of the offices in this building. its got beautiful stairways but no one is allowed to use them anymore.

data.title: Landmark Building with Rich History
data.text: The Tweed Courthouse is a landmark building with a fascinating history. Even if you don't have a lot of time, it only takes a few minutes to stop into their lobby - the restoration is wonderful!

data.title: Famous Building of "Boss" Tweed
data.text: This magnificent building is right behind City Hall. It symbolizes the corruption of New York City in the late 1800's. Unfortunately, we did not make arrangements in advance and were unable to enter the building.

data.title: ONE OF THE TOP HISTORICAL   BUILDINGS IN NEW YORK CITY
data.text: A wonderful restored building full of New York City history.  It is just too bad more of the building is not open to the public.

data.title: Beautiful restoration, ridiculous utilization
data.text: Mayor Bloomberg chose to relocate the Board of Education here,  rather than house the Museum of the City of New York in this historic building,  renovated for hundreds of millions of dollars.  Security is tight,  and there's nothing to see except multilayered bureaucrats.

data.title: Very interesting building
data.text: We are not architect types at all hut found this building very interesting and possibly the most interesting looking in all of New York!  What's more there is a rich history that surrounds the building and what went on inside, particularly interesting is the stories of corruption and plundering of the city's money during the nineteenth century.  We did like the stylish interior that you can imagine all that talking going on while sipping expensive whiskey and smoking big fat cigars, reminiscent of a very upscale jazz club

data.title: Walk past it almost every day
data.text: I know its part on NYC history and is a must see.  I live close by and just like WTC I never go in. However, it must be seen by visitors as it is a part of our history. Boss Tweed and the $1,000. toilet seats, etc. I see lots of tourists around the area. City Hall next door.

data.title: Beaux Arts at its Beauxest
data.text: This beautiful building was lavishly appointed with dollars that might have better been spent elsewhere, but those moneys designed and decorated this building thanks to the somewhat corrupt William Marcy Tweed--the man exposed in all those Thomas Nast political cartoons of the mid to late 19th century. The amount of dollars that it took to furbish the public space in this building was very scandalous at the time. On the other hand, we are left with a free to visit building open to the public that is a beautiful monument to lavish spending at a time when money was needed for more important things than decoration.

data.title: Magnificent restoration
data.text: It was slated to become the Museum of the City of New York,  with access to all, but it was hijacked by Mayor Bloomberg as headquarters for the Board of Education.  Complete waste.

data.title: A beautiful classical building.
data.text: I always love to pass by - and usually take a photo! This is a beautiful classic NYC administrative building.

data.title: Rough
data.text: The neighborhood was a bit scary and dirty. The court house itself is beautiful, just the homeless around was creeping me out.

data.title: One Extravgant Building
data.text: Tweed Courthouse is not a spectacular structure in comparison to other buildings in the city; but is famous because Boss Tweed used the building of it in the mid-nineteenth century to let out contracts to various individuals and business from which he received enormous kickbacks making him at the time the third largest property holder in the city and one of the richest men in the city.  Corruption in New York City politics was nothing new at the time, but plunder of the city's treasury had never before (or since) reached such colossal dimensions.  If you should come to the area see City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge and the Municipal Building, if behooves you to also take a look at the Tweed Courthouse.  Joseph London, licensed New York City tour guide.

data.title: Near NYC's City Hall--worth a peek.
data.text: When you're in Lower Manhattan in the vicintity of City Hall, City Hall Park, and the Woolworth Bldg-- all worth checking out--visit the Tweed Courthouse, infamous for its backroom dealings earlhy 20t c. NYC. The interior is especially evocative of cigar smoking, brandy drinking, political wheeling dealing (check out the WAY oversize fireplaces)/

data.title: A piece of history
data.text: Tammany Hall and an era gone by. Nope they don't make buildings like this anymore. There is an exhibit on ground floor.

data.title: Magnificent Lobby
data.text: If you are on your way to Chinatown after a 9/11 Memorial visit - just step into the lobby of this extraordinary building.   You will be amazed.
